description: Sri Lanka's President stressed in a meeting on March 17th the need of taking swift action against those who spread rumours and fabricated stories regarding the spread of the virus, with the intention of frightening the general public.

Sri Lanka's police spokesman announced on July 12 that the criminal investigations department is monitoring those spreading false information and rumors over social media and that stern action would take place against those caught doing so.

description:
Sri Lanka’s Ministry of Education has decided to close all government schools in the country from March 13th until April 20 due to the risk of coronavirus spreading in the country. Catholic and Buddhist Dhamma schools will also be closed till April 20th.  The closure was then extended to May 11 and then extended further indefinitely. The closure of these schools has been cancelled from June 29 onward, and is set to reopen in four stages. 
 UPDATE: The original policy of public school closure that was set to first last until April 20 and then up to May 11 and then extended until further notice has been cancelled from June 29 onward. Schools are now set to reopen from June 29 in four stages.

description:
On March 18th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that police curfew has been imposed in the Puttalam and Chilaw police divisions and Kochchikade in the Negombo Police Division from 4.30pm until further notice with the aim or controlling the spread of the Coronavirus (Covid-19).

The police curfew has been imposed to prevent the flouting of rules and regulations imposed under the quarantine and disease prevention Ordinance.

Those engaging in placing deposits for election and handing over nominations and those reporting for work will be permitted to travel.

Further, all essential services and public transport through these areas would also not be hampered despite the curfew being imposed.
On 19th March, 2020, Sri Lanka's Government Information Department announced that curfew has been imposed in the Wattala and Ja-Ela Police Divisions from 10.00 pm until further notice.
Sri Lanka's Presidential Secretariat announced that curfew will be imposed country-wide from 6.00 pm (March 20) until 6.00 am on Monday (March 23).

On March 18th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that police curfew has been imposed in the Puttalam and Chilaw police divisions and Kochchikade in the Negombo Police Division from 4.30pm until further notice with the aim or controlling the spread of the Coronavirus (Covid-19).

The police curfew has been imposed to prevent the flouting of rules and regulations imposed under the quarantine and disease prevention Ordinance.

Those engaging in placing deposits for election and handing over nominations and those reporting for work will be permitted to travel.

Further, all essential services and public transport through these areas would also not be hampered despite the curfew being imposed. UPDATE: The curfew has now been imposed on the whole nation from 6pm March 20 to 6am March 23, 2020.

On 19th March, 2020, Sri Lanka's Government Information Department announced that curfew has been imposed in the Wattala and Ja-Ela Police Divisions from 10.00 pm until further notice. UPDATE: The curfew is now imposed on the whole nation from 6pm March 20 to 6am March 23, 2020.

On 19th March, 2020, Sri Lanka's Government Information Department announced that curfew has been imposed in the Wattala and Ja-Ela Police Divisions from 10.00 pm until further notice. UPDATE: Sri Lanka is announced a country-wide curfew will take place on March 20.

Sri Lanka extended the curfew imposed in the districts of Mannar, Vavuniya, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi, and Jaffna in the Northern Province from March 23rd till 6.00 a.m. on Tuesday (March 24).

The curfew which will be lifted at 6.00 am on Tuesday will be re-imposed at 2.00 p.m. on the same day until further notice.

The travel ban will continue to be in effect until all those who visited and associated with the COVID-19 infected pastor who arrived from Switzerland recently are identified. UPDATE: The curfew imposed in the districts of Mannar, Vavuniya, Mullaitivu, Kilinochchi, and Jaffna in the Northern Province has been extended till 6.00 a.m. on Tuesday March 24th

Sri Lanka is re-imposing a curfew in the whole nation at 2pm 23 March 2020 till 6am 24 March 2020.
This policy does not apply to the Colombo, Gamapaha and Puttalam districts as their curfew had already been extended. UPDATE: The curfew was extended for Vavuniya, Jaffna, Kilinochchi, Mannar and Mullaitivu until 24 March, 2020.

It is now voided because the curfew in Colombo, Gampaha, Puttalam and five districts in the Northern province has been re-imposed at 12 noon March 24, 2020. Additionally, the previous curfew in the other districts had been extended until 26 March, 2020.

description:
Sri Lanka's Presidential Secretariat announced that curfew will be imposed country-wide from 6.00 pm (March 20) until 6.00 am on Monday (March 23). 

While curfew is still in force, civilian life in the distrits of Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara and Puttalam will resume from Monday, the May 11th.

In the rest of the districts curfew will be on from 8.00pm o 5.00 will be in force till 5.00am on Monday, May 11th. UPDATE: While curfew is still in force, civilian life in the distrits of Colombo, Gampaha, Kalutara and Puttalam will resume from Monday, the May 11th .

Sri Lanka's president of media division announced on May 28 that a nationwide curfew will be imposed on select days, namely, May 31, June 4 and June 5. The statement also said, "from June 1 to June 3, curfew will be imposed in all districts of the country from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time while from June 6 onwards, curfew will be imposed from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time daily until further notice."

Sri Lanka's president of media division announced on May 28 that a nationwide curfew will be imposed on select days, namely, May 31, June 4 and June 5. The statement also said, "from June 1 to June 3, curfew will be imposed in all districts of the country from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time while from June 6 onwards, curfew will be imposed from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time daily until further notice." UPDATE: The policy ended as Sri Lanka lifted all curfews and lock downs island wide on June 28.
On June 13 it was announced that the daily curfew in Sri Lanka will be imposed from 12 midnight to 4 a.m until further notice.

Sri Lanka's president of media division announced on May 28 that a nationwide curfew will be imposed on select days, namely, May 31, June 4 and June 5. The statement also said, "from June 1 to June 3, curfew will be imposed in all districts of the country from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time while from June 6 onwards, curfew will be imposed from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. local time daily until further notice." On June 13 it was announced that the curfew time would change and be from 12 midnight to 4 a.m. UPDATE: The daily curfew imposed on June 6 was from 10 p.m to 4 a.m was changed to a curfew imposed daily from June 13 from 12 midnight to 4 a.m.

On June 13 it was announced that the daily curfew in Sri Lanka will be imposed from 12 midnight to 4 a.m until further notice. UPDATE: The policy ended on June 28 as Sri Lanka lifted any curfew/lock down island wide.

On January 26th 2020, Sri Lanka announced that all passengers from flights originated from China need to be screened for temperature. If a passenger with elevated temperature is detected, he/she should be given a surgical mask to wear and taken to the health office.
   
   All suspected 2019-nCoV patients need to be screened by airport health office (APHO) medical officers. Consent for examination and further assessment should be obtained from the traveler or parent of guardian. If consent is not given, the traveler/s will be managed under the authority given by the Quarantine and Prevention of Diseases Ordinance.
   
   If the traveler has a contact history and fever/signs and symptoms, the traveler should be transferred to IDH/ designated hospitals.Director or a designed officer from these hospitals should immediately contact the Chief Epidemiologist and the D Quarantine and should immediately provide relevant patient information for required surveillance, prevention and further actions.
   
   Passengers Locator Form should be filled for those travelers with suspected nCoV seated in the same row and two rows in front and behind the index suspected case. The details should be communicated to the Epidemiology Unit, which will carry out the community level contact tracing and house quarantine of asymptomatic contacts with the help of Regional Epidemiologist and MOOH.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The government of Sri Lanka announced that all international airports in Sri Lanka will be closed to arriving international commercial passenger flights from 19 March to 25 March, 2020, which has been subsequently extended.

Sri Lanka is temporarily suspending all types of Electronic Travel Authorizations (ETA)/ Entry Visas, Landing Endorsements, Multiple Entry Visas and Residence Visas already granted and the foreign nationals will not be allowed to enter Sri Lanka temporarily. This policy will take effect from 2020.03.19, 0400hrs (Local Time in Sri Lanka) to 2020.03.25 2359 hrs (Local Time in Sri Lanka).

description:
The government of Sri Lanka announced that all international airports in Sri Lanka will be closed to arriving international commercial passenger flights from 19 March to 25 March, 2020, which has been subsequently extended.

The Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 has recommended on May 26th the reopening airports from August 1, seeking to end a four-month long shutdown following the outbreak of the coronavirus. UPDATE: Sri lanka - The Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 has recommended on May 26th the reopening airports from August 1, seeking to end a four-month long shutdown following the outbreak of the coronavirus.

description: Sri Lanka Minister of Industry, Export, Investment Promotion, Tourism and Aviation Prasanna Ranatunga said that all passengers arriving in the country will undergo PCR tests for COVID-19, begin on June 1st at the Bandaranaike International Airport (BIA) premises.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)

description:
Sri Lanka - Kimali Fernando, chairperson of the Sri Lanka Tourism Promotion Bureau, said on May 31st that a limited number of small groups from around the world would be allowed to visit from August and stay in approved five-star hotels that have put strict safety measures in place. 

Tourists will be required to carry a COVID-19-free certificate issued either by their governments or a reputed agency. Tourists would also need to wait on arrival at the airport for coronavirus testing. Fernando also confirmed that individual travelers will still not be allowed to enter the country.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health and Indigenous Medical Services announced on April 12th approaches to strenghen hospital emergency preparedness and response plan for COVID-19. Currently there is a three tier approach including 1) designated COVID-19 treatment facilities, 2) COVID-19 Isolation hospitals, and 3) Identified centers with ICU/HDU facilities.
type_sub_cat: Hospitals

description: Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health and Indigenous Medical Services announced on April 12th approaches to strenghen hospital emergency preparedness and response plan for COVID-19. description:
On January 26th, Sri Lanka announced testing criteria for Novel Coronavirus (nCoV): 1) Patients with severe acute respiratory infection (fever, cough, and requiring admission to hospital), AND with no other aetiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND at least one of the following: 
a. history of travel to or residence in the city of Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or
b. Patient is a heath care worker who has been working in an environment  where severe acute respiratory infections of unknown aetiology are being cared for. 
2) Patients with any acute respiratory illness AND at least one of the following: 
a. close contact with a confirmed or probable case of 2019-nCoV in the 14 days prior to illness onset, or 
b. visiting or working in a live animal market in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China in the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or 
c. Worked or attended a health care facility in the 14 days prior to onset of symptoms where patients with hospital-associated 2019-nCov infections have been reported.

Sri Lanka Ministry of Health & Indigenous Medical Services's Epidemiology Unit unveiled on May 9th COVID-19 laboratory test strategy based on RT-PCR assay. The test strategy is divided into 2 categories: case finding (active and passive) and epidemiological investigation (sentinel surveillance, random sampling of selected communities, sero-prevalance studies).
Sri Lanka's Medical Research Institute announced on May 18 that the number of PCR tests will increase from 3000 per day to 6000 per day soon.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Sri Lanka announced on July 30 that random covid-19 tests will be conducted island wide.
Sri Lanka has decided to disinfect buses and trains used for public transportation from 14 March 2020.

Sri Lanka announced on April 18th the following hygiene measures for resumption of normal day to day activities during COVID-19. "Ensure strict compliance with regard to social distancing, wearing of face masks, hand washing and other measures in all Government offices in all districts. Maintain all workplaces in clean and sanitary condition. Workplaces that have frequent visits by the general public in particular should provide access to hand washing with soap and water and/or to sanitizing hand rub dispensers placed in prominent locations in workplace premises."
type_sub_cat: Hygiene measures for public areas

description: It was announced on 28 April that Sri Lanka had commissioned a Passenger Disinfection Chamber to be used at the Bandaranaika International Airport.
type_sub_cat: Hygiene measures for public areas

description: On 3 March, 2020, the Ministry of Buddha Sasana and Religious & Cultural Affairs in Sri Lanka advises the general public to avoid from engaging in local pilgrimages, tours and journeys over the next two weeks.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Sri Lanka government announced on April 5th that traveling to and from all districts has been completely prohibited except for the purpose of providing essential services.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 31, 2020 in Sri Lanka, The Atulugama village in Kalutara was declared an isolated area by the government after a patient tested positive for the coronavirus. Entry to or exit from this village has been completely prohibited. UPDATE: The Atulugama area has been reopened after ending the isolation period on 14 April, 2020.
According to the Department of Railways, the Unawatuna railway station in Sri Lanka has been closed on July 13 due to Covid-19 spike in cases.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within a country

description: Sri Lanka President's Media Division announced on April 26th that people will be allowed to go outside to make essential purchases and to attend to vital activities based on the last digit of their National Identity Card (NIC) numbers. Police and the armed forces personnel would keep track of people who violate health instructions and regulations.In the event an area is demarcated as an isolated area, no one will be allowed to enter or leave these areas.

Sri Lanka President's Media Division announced on April 26th that people will be allowed to go outside to make essential purchases and to attend to vital activities based on the last digit of their National Identity Card (NIC) numbers. Police and the armed forces personnel would keep track of people who violate health instructions and regulations.In the event an area is demarcated as an isolated area, no one will be allowed to enter or leave these areas. On May 26, this ended as curfew was lifted island-wide and is in place only from 10 p.m to 4 a.m until further notice. UPDATE: The original policy which allowed people with different numbers on their National Identity Card to leave their homes on different days to purchase essential items ended with the lifting of the curfew on May 26 May

Sri Lanka inaugurated 'National Operation Centre for Prevention of COVID-19 Outbreak' (NOCPCO) on March 21st, 2020. the Centre is established on the guidelines given by HE the President Gotabaya Rajapaksa with the objective of centralizing, expediting and implementing all necessary preventive and containing measures against the transmission of COVID - 19 pandemic. This Centre is headed by Lieutenant General Shavendra Silva, Chief of Defence Sta􀃠 and Commander of the Army.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
Sri Lanka established the Presidential Task Force on March 26th to combat COVID – 19 with the responsibility to ensure that the civilian life moves on without any hindrance. 

The Special Representative of the President Basil Rajapaksa has been appointed as the Chairman of the Task Force while Additional Secretary to the Prime Minister Anton Perera serves as the Secretary.

The membership of the Task Force is 40 including Provincial Governors, several Secretaries to Ministries, Commanders of Tri-Forces, security chiefs including Acting Inspector General of Police, Chairmen of several Departments, Corporations and Authorities and District and Divisional Secretaries.

The President had declared powers and functions of the Task Force through a special gazette notification.

The Task Force should carry out its responsibilities covering every district in the country while giving priority to districts of Colombo, Kalutara, Gampaha, Puttalam, Jaffana, Mannar, Kilinochchi, Vavuniya and Mullaitivu which have been identified as fasing a greater risk.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description:
The Sri Lanka Telecommunication Regulatory Commission stated on March 23rd that, based on TRCSL guidance all operators have agreed and now have a mechanism to provide emergency credit and extra talk time for prepaid customers who may face difficulty purchasing top-ups due to curfew.

The TRCSL also said that, “All operators have agreed to provide uninterrupted services for all customers inline. “
type_text: Sri Lanka telecommunication operators agreed to provide uninterrupted services for all customers inline during Corona crisis
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Sri Lanka President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had set up a special fund “COVID – 19 Healthcare and Social Security Fund” to strengthen the mitigation activities aimed at controlling the spread of COVID-19 virus in the country and related social welfare programmes.

President Rajapaksa has instructed to donate Rs. 100 million from the President’s Fund for this purpos
type_text: Sri Lanka President set up a special fund aimed to control the spread of COVID-19 and for related social welfare

description: On 27 March 2020, the Sri Lankan government has introduced a mechanism to deliver drugs to the doorstep of houses through pharmacies in the area.
type_text: The government introduced a mechanism to deliver drugs to the doorstep of houses through pharmacies in the area. Identified pharmacies can be accessed by the given websites. Payment is made online or in cash on delivery. In order to purchase the drugs, a recently obtained prescription needs to be sent via WhatsApp/Viber/Imo to the selected pharmacy. The pharmacy will deliver drugs within 24 hrs. Instructions on consumption of the prescribed drugs and the phone number of the pharmacist will be displayed on the cover.

description: Sri Lanka launched an awareness programme on COVID – 19 on March 13th for the staff members of Ministries, Departments and Corporations. Dr. Deshantha Dissanayake enlightened the staff on symptoms, prevention and precautionary measures relating to COVID -19. Accordingly, this will continue at both State and private sector entities.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
Sri Lanka's Health Promotion Bureau has introduced a telephone hotline for all inquiries related to the Coronavirus on March 27th. 

"The hotline is 1999 and is operational round the clock (24 hours) and information could be obtained in all three languages, Sinhala, Tamil and English. The Suvaseriya Health Promotion Bureau's medical advice hotline is aimed at providing accurate information to the public and preventing the spread of false information."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On April 3, Sri Lanka's police implemented a public awareness program that aimed to educate residents on social distancing.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 17th, Sri Lanka urged people who entered the country from Italy, South Korea and Iran between March 1 to 9 to undergo self-quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: According to the Public Health Inspectors’ Union of Sri Lanka, it was announced on July 15 that over 3000 people from 16 districts have been directed to self quarantine, due to contact tracing and the sudden surge in covid-19 cases in the island.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description:
Sri Lanka declared March 20th to 27th as ‘Work from home week’ for both public and private sectors.

This duration is not public holidays except March 21st and 22nd.
type_sub_cat: Commercial Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
Sri Lanka declared March 20th to 27th as ‘Work from home week’ for both public and private sectors.

This duration is not public holidays except March 21st and 22nd. 

This order has since been updated on April 5th to last till April 10th. UPDATE: The original work from home order for both public and private sectors last till March 27th has been extended till April 10th.
type_sub_cat: Commercial Businesses

description:
Sri Lanka announced the duration from March 30th to April 03rd had been declared as a Work from Home period.

This will apply to all State, semi-government and private sector entities except which are categorized as essential services. UPDATE: The Work from home policy is extended from March 27th to April 3rd
type_sub_cat: Commercial Businesses
type_text: Sri Lanka President set up a special fund aimed to control the spread of COVID-19 and for related social welfare
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
Sri Lanka declared March 20th to 27th as ‘Work from home week’ for both public and private sectors, which has since been extended.

This duration is not public holidays except March 21st and 22nd.

On April 18th, the government announced that for government offices, each head of institution shall determine the type of work to be carried out via work from home arrangements, the specific employees to attend to such work, the frequency of employees reporting to work during the week etc. UPDATE: Head of Institution can now determine the type of work to be carried out via work form home arrangements, the specific employees to attend to such work, the frequency of employees reporting to work during the week, etc.
type_sub_cat: Commercial Businesses

description: The Judicial Service Commission in Sri Lanka have issued instructions to all High Court Judges/Judicial Officers and Presidents of Labour Tribunals, with the aim of preventing the spread of the said virus. The objective of these measures is to minimize crowding in courthouses. This will be operative from 17th to 20th March 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Public courts
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Sri Lanka's Director General of Health Services announced that there was a ban on all public events and gatherings for a period of two weeks from March 14.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description:
Sri Lanka announced on March 16th more measures to limit congregation of people in the wake of COVID – 19 outbreak in the country.

The congregation of public near prisons will also be limited. However, normal commercial, banking and trading activities will continue as usual.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Sri Lanka has released 2,961 prison inmates on bail between the period from March 17th to April 4th under the recommendations of the special committee appointed by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Sri Lanka established on March 25th a special mechanism to deliver essential food items to homes. Medicine will be delivered to the homes of regular patients who have registered at hospitals with the support of Divisional Secretaries, Public Health Officers and the security forces. Authorities was requested to implement a programme to supply domestic gas at consumer’s doorstep responding to the telephone orders.

The objective of the entire project is to prevent the public from gathering at market places so that the health sector’s efforts to combat the coronavirus could be a success.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Announced on 7 April 2020, Sri Lanka is introducing a mechanism to streamline the issuing of curfew permits to avoid people gathering in large numbers to get curfew permits.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 50 or more employees located in Colombo District of Western province will be issued by the Police Headquarters.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 50 or more employees  will be issued by the Office of the Deputy Inspector General of Police in Charge of the Province that they are located.

Curfew permits for Industries/Institutions/Companies with 10-50 employees located in each Police Division will be issued by the respective Offices of the Superintendents of Police in Charge of the Divisions.

Curfew permits for industries/institutions/companies with less than 10 employees and individuals on extreme humanitarian reasons are issued by police stations.
Sri Lanka announced that it was postponing its parliamentary elections by 2 months to June 20.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Sri Lanka's Health Ministry announced on May 20 that public events and gatherings will be permitted with a maximum limit of 25 persons per event/gathering. The ministry also mentioned that whenever possible, these events and gatherings should be avoided.

Sri Lanka's Director General of Health Services announced that there was a ban on all public events and gatherings for a period of two weeks from March 14. Although no announcement was made on extending the ban, on May 20 it was announced by the Health Ministry that public events and gatherings were now permitted with a maximum limit of 25 persons per event/gathering. UPDATE: The original ban on public events and gatherings was announced on March 14 and was set to last for 2 weeks. Although no announcement was made on extending the ban, on May 20 it was announced that public events and gatherings will be allowed, although with a cap of 25 persons per event.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: Sri Lanka's Health Ministry announced on May 20 that public events and gatherings will be permitted with a maximum limit of 25 persons per event/gathering. The ministry also mentioned that whenever possible, these events and gatherings should be avoided. On May 22 the policy was updated to allow 100 persons to attend an event or gathering. The policy requires that the wearing of masks and social distancing has to be followed. UPDATE: The original policy that was announced on May 20 allowed public events and gatherings and had a maximum limit of 25 persons per event/gathering. The policy has now been updated to allow a maximum of 100 persons per event/gathering.

Sri Lanka announced that it was postponing its parliamentary elections by 2 months to June 20.  On June 10 it was announced that the elections have been further postponed to August 5. UPDATE: Sri lanka's parliamentary elections which were delayed by 2 months to June 20, has now been postponed to August 5.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: Sri Lanka's Health Ministry announced on May 20 that public events and gatherings will be permitted with a maximum limit of 25 persons per event/gathering. The ministry also mentioned that whenever possible, these events and gatherings should be avoided.  On July 7 it was announced that gatherings such as weddings will allow a maximum limit of 300 persons per event and should be limited at a 50% seating capacity. UPDATE: The policy on a limit of number of guests per gathering has been increased from 25 to 300 people.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description: On July 12 it was announced by the president of Sri Lanka that all rallies on July 12, 13 and 14 for the upcoming parliamentary elections was cancelled.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On July 18 it was announced that Sri Lanka had issued strict guidelines for the upcoming parliamentary elections. It included the restriction of people in rallies to 300 people and could be increased to up to 500 people if the party leader was present.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description: Sri Lanka's director general of health services, stated on March 24, that social distancing of one meter apart should be maintained at all times. He reiterated that social distancing should continue even after the curfew that was imposed is lifted.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy

description: Sri Lanka's director general of health services, stated on March 24, that social distancing of one meter apart should be maintained at all times. He reiterated that social distancing should continue even after the curfew that was imposed is lifted. On May 25, it was announced that Police could arrest anyone not complying with this social distancing policy from May 26 onward. UPDATE: The original social distancing policy of at least one meter apart was first advised on March 24 and not enforced as mandatory. On May 25 it was announced that the police could arrest anyone not complying with this policy from May 26 onward.
type_sub_cat: Other Mask Wearing Policy

description: Sri Lanka's police announced on June 27 that from June 28 onward, it was compulsory to wear masks when outdoors. Violators of this policy will be quarantined for 14 days.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)
